What's the intuition behind the tangent bundle of a tangent bundle T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M))?

If T(M)T(M)T(M) has two coordinates (a point and a vector), then how many coordinates does T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)) have? A lecture from Geoffrey Cruttwell on the tangent categories workshop seems to suggest there's four coordinates (at 13:14 timestamp), but I'm not sure how to visualise that. If T(X)T(X)T(X) consists of a point xxx in XXX and a vector at that point, then shouldn't T(T(M)T(T(M)T(T(M) consist of a point in T(M)T(M)T(M) (i.e. already a pair (m,v)(m, v)(m,v) of a point and a vector) and a tangent vector www at (m,v):T(M)(m, v) : T(M)(m,v):T(M) that point?

Though, even though the three-coordinate option seems more sensible, I'm still not sure how to visualise it, or get any intuition about what the second tangent vector represents
T(T(M)) has four times the dimensions of M, yes.

What do the last two components represent?
If I have an element (m,v):T(M)(m, v) : T(M)(m,v):T(M), then vvv can be thought of as a change in mmm.
If I have an element (m,v,w,z):T(T(M))(m, v, w, z) : T(T(M))(m,v,w,z):T(T(M)), then vvv can be thought of as a change in mmm, but how do I think of www and zzz?
www is another change in mmm, while zzz is a change in vvv.

Oh, so a tangent bundle of a pair type tells us how both of these elements change, not just how the "last one" changes? For some reason I was not expecting this... but it does seem more natural that I think about it now
The tangent bundle construction takes as input a manifold, not a bundle, so it doesn't care about that. Maybe you are thinking of some kind of fibrewise tangent bundle construction.

Physicists think a lot about T(T(M)). A point in M can represent the position qqq of a particle. A point (q,v)∈(q,v) \in(q,v)∈ T(M) then represents its position and velocity. In the Lagrangian approach to dynamics, the way position and velocity change over time is described by a vector field on T(T(M)). So, for any point (q,v)(q,v)(q,v) in T(M) we get a point in T(T(M)) that describes the rate at which position and velocity change over time. Usually a consistency condition holds, which says that the rate at which position changes is equal to the velocity!

Right, I think I didn't internalise properly that T(MT(MT(M is a manifold itself. The outside TTT has no idea that we're giving it a manifold which already had TTT applied to it.

Points in T(M)T(M)T(M) are black boxes which have two components: the base point, and the change vector itself. Applying TTT to it gives us a pair of black boxes, one original pair (m,v)(m ,v)(m,v), and a new one telling us how both mmm and vvv itself can be changed.

To think about these things mathematically, it's worth noting that like any bundle, there's a projection

πM:T(M)→M \pi_M : T(M) \to MπM​:T(M)→M

Taking the differential of πM\pi_MπM​, we get

dπM:T(T(M))→T(M)d \pi_M : T(T(M)) \to T(M)dπM​:T(T(M))→T(M).

(We could call this ddd here "TTT" to indicate that it's just the functor TTT applied to a morphism, but geometers don't do this.)

But also, because T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)) is a bundle over T(M)T(M)T(M), we have a map

πT(M):T(T(M))→T(M) \pi_{T(M)} : T(T(M)) \to T(M)πT(M)​:T(T(M))→T(M)

So, you should think about comparing these two ways to get a guy in T(M)T(M)T(M) from a guy in T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)). They're not equal!

This is connected to my remark

Usually a consistency condition holds, which says that the rate at which position changes is equal to the velocity!

and how you state this condition.

Ah, right, so we've got two maps of type T(T(M))→T(M)T(T(M)) \to T(M)T(T(M))→T(M). Let me see if I can get this right. The first one TπMT\pi_MTπM​ takes a quadruple (m,v,m′,v′)(m, v, m', v')(m,v,m′,v′) to (m,m′(m, m'(m,m′). This is because πM\pi_MπM​ just projects out the base point of MMM, so TπMT\pi_MTπM​ should project out the base point and the change over it. The second one just projects out the base point of T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)), i.e. (m,v)(m, v)(m,v)
Though, now that I wrote it, I'm suspicious whether (m,m′)(m, m')(m,m′) can be of type T(M)T(M)T(M)

I suppose it can, but the question is, what is the type of m′m'm′? I suppose it should be the "space of changes over m", i.e. the same type as v′v'v′? In which case it's all fine and the result typechecks

m∈Mm \in Mm∈M
v∈TmMv \in T_m Mv∈Tm​M

and

(m′,v′)∈T(m,v)(TM)(m',v') \in T_{(m,v)} (TM)(m′,v′)∈T(m,v)​(TM)

so what you're wondering about is whether you can interpret m′m'm′ as an element of TmMT_m MTm​M.

I think what's really going on is that you need to use the two maps I mentioned to deal with m′m'm′ and v′v'v′, and even show that an element of T(m,v)(TM)T_{(m,v)} (TM)T(m,v)​(TM) deserves to be written as a pair. Your intuitions are right, it just takes some work to formally justify them!

I've always tried to keep a low dimensional example in my head to make things easier to visualize. I like this picture from Wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangent_bundle#/media/File:Tangent_bundle.svg

Say MMM is the circle whose coordinate is called α\alphaα, then the tangent spaces are the red lines. Let's just call a tangent vector α˙\dot{\alpha}α˙ since it could represent a path's velocity along α\alphaα. We rearrange the tangent spaces into a cylinder to get the tangent bundle T(M)T(M)T(M), so the velocity is now represented by height along the cylinder.

A tangent space in T(M)T(M)T(M) is going to be a plane touching the cylinder, so the bundle T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)) will indeed be 4 dimensional. Unfortunately it's already hard to visualize the bundle since we've run out of spatial dimensions. But you can imagine the planes rearranged in the same way that we rearranged the tangent lines. So a vector in a tangent plane will have a component along α\alphaα and a component along α˙\dot{\alpha}α˙. The component along α˙\dot{\alpha}α˙ could obviously represent acceleration α¨\ddot{\alpha}α¨, but I'm also unsure of what the α\alphaα-component could represent physically in terms of paths.

Every curve on MMM of coordinates {mi(t)}\{m_i(t)\}{mi​(t)} also gives a curve on TMTMTM by looking at the tangent vectors, that is, coordinates {mi(t),m˙j(t)}\{m_i(t), \dot{m}_j(t)\}{mi​(t),m˙j​(t)}. Iterating the procedure we get a curve on TTMTTMTTM but you see that, this way, the second and third components in TTMTTMTTM are going to be equal. (This is due to the fact that we started from MMM.)
Indeed in geometry (differential, symplectic, contact geometry,...) is interesting to see which vector fields on TTMTTMTTM come from motions on MMM and which do not -- and one can ask for similar questions on other bundles as well.

When these things are axiomatized as a [[tangent bundle category]] there are two operations assumed as non-trivial structure. The latter seems relevant here.

Vertical lift T⇒T2T\Rightarrow T^2T⇒T2:
ℓ(m,v)=(m,0,0,v)\ell(m,v) = (m,0,0,v)ℓ(m,v)=(m,0,0,v)

Canonical flip T2⇒T2T^2\Rightarrow T^2T2⇒T2:
c(m,v,m′,v′)=(m,m′,v,v′)c(m,v,m',v')=(m,m',v,v')c(m,v,m′,v′)=(m,m′,v,v′)

Yes! I guess Bruno has a choice whether to first learn differential geometry in one of the usual ways and then see why the tangent bundle (which can be defined in various equivalent ways) has these structures, or first learn about tangent bundle categories and then turn to the category of manifolds as an example.

I defined those maps without using any description of points of T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)) as 4-tuples. We just need "a point in T(X)T(X)T(X) is a pair (x,v)(x,v)(x,v) consisting of x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and v∈TxXv \in T_x Xv∈Tx​X". We need to use this definition twice to describe points of T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)).

We get that a point of T(T(M))T(T(M))T(T(M)) is a triple (m,v,w)(m,v,w)(m,v,w) where m∈M,v∈TmMm \in M, v \in T_m Mm∈M,v∈Tm​M and w∈T(m,v)TMw \in T_{(m,v)} TM w∈T(m,v)​TM.

So then the question becomes, how can we describe www more concretely?

For this it helps to consider the map

πM:T(M)→M \pi_M : T(M) \to MπM​:T(M)→M

which sends (m,v)(m,v)(m,v) to mmm, and its differential

dπM:T(T(M))→T(M)d \pi_M : T(T(M)) \to T(M)dπM​:T(T(M))→T(M).

defined using the fact that TTT is a functor - not defined using any stuff about triples or quadruples.
This latter map gives a way to extract an element of T(M)T(M)T(M), and thus an element of TmMT_m MTm​M, out of our triple (m,v,w)(m,v,w)(m,v,w). This element is not vvv! It's something else.

I see. I suppose the main idea is to understand how TTT acts on the projection map πM:TM→M\pi_M : TM \to MπM​:TM→M. Am I supposed to look at how the action of TTT is defined on morphisms? If I do so, the action of TTT on a map f:M→Nf : M \to Nf:M→N is defined as (m,v)↦(f(m),D(f)(m,v))(m, v) \mapsto (f(m), D(f)(m, v))(m,v)↦(f(m),D(f)(m,v)) (from here), where D(f)(m,v)D(f)(m, v)D(f)(m,v) tells us how much changing mmm and vvv affects the output. So in this case, changing vvv doesn't do anything, since it's not used. Changing mmm does.

So I suppose that alone tells me that the www from above is a pair: we need to account for changing mmm and vvv. I.e. T(πM):TTM→TM:=((m,v),(m′,v′))↦(m,m′)T(\pi_M) : TTM \to TM := ((m, v), (m', v')) \mapsto (m, m')T(πM​):TTM→TM:=((m,v),(m′,v′))↦(m,m′).
